captions.text:
We are here to talk about
why your cat beats you up.
Now, let's go get catified.

Today, we are in the land
of the supermarket question.

The supermarket question
is, Jackson, I got this cat,
he's really, really cool.

And every time we're sitting
together, out of the blue,
randomly he attacks me.

Of course, its never
out of the blue.

It's always because
of something.

And secondly, yes, you may have
bites and scratches on you,
but is that an attack?

Most times, when
folks are sitting here

just like me and him,
we're just sitting around,

we're not doing much of
anything-- good PC, good PC,
oh I love PC.
Look at this, look at this.
Bye, PC.
See you, PC.
Right?
And gone.
Why is that?

Petting-induced
overstimulation aggression.

And what happens there
is that certain cats--

and this is physiological,
this is not a matter

of temperament-- cannot take
being pet like this over
and over the over again.

It actually fills them
with a sort of static,

like a balloon, filled,
filled, and then bang.

You don't realize when
you're sitting watching TV

with your cat how
you're petting them.
So what is the cure for this?

All right, let's
look at number one.
Be observant.

Know when your cat
is getting worked up.

As you're petting, you're
going to notice the tail start
to twitch just a little.

And then that graduates, and
then starts going like this.

And then, you are
going to get bit.

Then there is what I
call back electricity.
Right down the back.

It's a cat going eew, ughh
In terms of stimulation,

they're just getting
to that point.

It's up to you to
notice these things.

And if you notice
that, the aggression
is not going to happen.

Know where your cat enjoys
being pet and for how long.

I'm going to demonstrate
with [? Veloria ?]

the opposite of
the full body pet.

Veloria, here, 23
years old of fun.

So now watch, out
comes the finger.

You see how she guides
me here with the finger?

Look at that, see
how she guides me?

This is a technique-- I wish
I had a better name for it.

Right now I call
it the finger nose.

I present my finger
like a nose to the cat.
The idea is to let them pet you.

Overstimulation
happens constantly

with cats because they are
this direct channel for energy.
Proactivity is key, folks.

You've got to play
with your cats.

You've got to get that
energy out on a regular basis

so then when they're
sitting on your lap,

that balloon is
not filled to 90%.

So all it takes is
five pets and kaboom.
They blow.

Again, remember,
you are in control

of putting air into
the cat balloon.

Let that air out
as the day goes on.

Don't keep putting air into
it, and don't be surprised
when the balloon pops.

From now on, when it
does happen to you--

I know this is really hard--
pull yourself emotionally out

of that moment and say,
what just happened here.

When you understand
that part of things,

you're going to stop blaming
the cat for doing things to you.

All right, folks, you can
find me pretty much anywhere.

If you want to find me,
#teamcatmojo, #mycatfromhell,

#teamanimojo, you'll see
a lot of these hashtags.
Just hashtag.

You know, I'm still looking
for more cats and dogs watching

my cat from hell, so if
you just #catswatchingmcfh,

#dogswatchingmcfh, we'll all
have a lot of fun doing that.

And also, send me in examples of
what you've done to your house

to environmentally
enrich that place.

#catification, and be on
the lookout for that book

"Catification" with my coauthor
Kate Benjamin, coming out
in October.

Couldn't be more
psyched for that one.

All right folks, until next
time, all light, all love,
and all mojo to ya.
Love ya.
(MUSIC) You're a bad cat.
I'm not a bad cat.
You're a bad cat.
I'm not a bad cat.
You're a bad cat.
I'm just misunderstood.
Meow.

comments.text:
I found this out by myself a long time ago. I use this finger-to-nose 
technique a lot.

It also seems cats prefer to be pet around the neck more than all the way 
down to the tail (though some cats prefer all the way).

I also don't force pet like some people...  I first see if the cat wants to 
be pet before I do it...  
People indeed cry about cats not being like dogs.. But just imagine someone 
comes up to you and starts petting you... during the most random moments of 
the day.. You might like some moments, you might dislike some moments.. 
same for the cat..

Some people just lack the ability to place themselves in the cats "paws". 
(shoes)﻿

comments.author: D Money

comments.text:
This is true for all animals! No animal wants to be pet harshly or have 
somebody's heavy hand drag across their body... especially if they're small 
like a cat, a puppy, a bunny, a bird, or whatever the hell you want to pet. 
Same goes with an animal as big as a horse or cow... if you're going to pet 
and animal, respect it. Don't wipe your hands over the animal to the point 
where its eyes are being pulled to the back of it's head. Be gentle.
I own pit bulls. People tell me all the time, "Aren't you scared? They 
attack for no reason". No, actually people miss the signs the dog gives. 
When your child is climbing on the dog and squealing in its ear and petting 
it roughly, the dog is toughing it out. But it can't do it for long. That's 
annoying for any animal to experience on a daily basis... bad for your 
mental and even physical health. Then one day the dog "attacks out of the 
blue" and the owners get rid of it. It's a shame because the owner is the 
irresponsible one. Put yourself in the dog's place. First, everybody is 
against your breed, so not many people have faith in you to begin with. 
Second, there's this child annoying the hell out of you, and you're 
expected to tolerate it the REST OF YOUR LIFE? No. It's time for the owners 
to get the child to stop and to help release that stress by walking the dog 
and playing with it.
All of this is pretty similar to a cat. As the video explained, cats really 
don't 'attack' for no reason... and that's also similar with all animals. 
You think a wolf is attacking your livestock for no reason!? No way... 
first, that land was the wolf's before it was yours. Second, that wolf is 
hungry and your livestock is a tasty meal. Third, you are a threat- plain 
and simple- and that wolf probably has a huge pack to protect.
All I can say is, ALWAYS respect animals. Love them. NEVER blame the 
animal. You can't beat mother nature. We as humans are very uneducated when 
it comes to understanding this world. Granted, I'm just a 15 year old girl 
myself and I have a lot to learn but at least I'm open minded and I'm 
willing to understand more about this world. Most adults have a mental age 
younger than my real age.﻿
comments.author: Mr.Sickboy

comments.text:
I have a cat that pee's on my kitchen wall and I have one that poops on the 
carpet in the bathroom. Arggg. The peeing cat I have yet to catch. The 
pooping cat has just started in the last few months. I know which cat it is 
but I don't know what to do to stop him. We are a 8 cat home. We have 2 
giant litter boxes that I scoop at least 3 times a day. Any idea ?﻿
comments.author: crazycatlady1313

comments.text:
+crazycatlady1313 I suggest taking the poop they dropped in the wrong place 
and transfer it to the litter box. Then try and remove the scent on the 
carpet as much as possible, maybe block access. The point is that the cat 
must smell where it's supposed to poop. If you catch them in the act, pick 
them up and put them in the box so they can finish there.

verbally and then half an hour later calling him he/she will run to you 
with love and slobber all over you.
Tell the cat off  and it will avoid you, and even if you face them and do

Cats are cool, yes even for humans.﻿

comments.text:
How do you tell if your cat is getting agitated if their tail never stops, 
even in their sleep? My cat is 14 and I've had her sense 8 weeks, and her 
tail doesn't stop she has to sit on it and wrestle it to clean it...in her 
sleep it moves sometimes small movements or twitches other times long 
lopes, but it doesn't sit still﻿
comments.author: Sam R

comments.text:
+Sam R That doesn't sound normal. It may be a nervous twitch, possibly 
because of old age. But other signs are the ears pulling back, not 
sideways, but back which indicates aggression. Or lifting its front paw, 
readying to claw at you. Sometimes you'll notice this icy stillness and it 
stares away from you. That's the moment where it's pissed off and ready to 
strike :p

comments.author: XxSarah5xX

comments.text:
My cats have their own petting schedule. I mean it's not whenever I want to 
pet them. It is whenever they want to get a nice massage. My black cat is 
the sweetest. You pet her, and she reward you with drippings from her nose. 
My second cat reward you with a tiny bit of purring. It is a lot to ask 
from him, because he isn't easily impressed. Then, when he is finally 
happy, he will grab your hand, hug it tight to his chest, rubbing his face 
on your palm, and BITE. My third cat is very special. He doesn't like you 
to pet him. I don't know what his problems are, but his body is very very 
sensitive. If you just poke his back gently, that piece of skin would jerk, 
then he would lick it a bit. But, every night he would purr like a 
generator, and watch you while you sleep. He likes it if you rub his face 
with a piece of cloth.﻿

comments.author: Live love makeup

comments.text: Jackson, thanks for the video. Very informative.﻿
comments.author: Malavos

comments.text:
I do the finger thing all the time with my cats--the older female 'guides' 
me to the top of her head and under her chin, and our little tom 'pet 
himself' with nose to tail strokes multiple times, and then wants to be 
picked up and cuddled (I'd think it's kinda hard to misinterpret a cat 
jumping into your arms and settling in) for a few minutes, then he's off 
again. Or asleep. ﻿
comments.author: Sherry Gordon

comments.text: I watched this whole petting my cat and he loved IT:)﻿
comments.author: Mathias Johansson

comments.text:
Super cool! Thanks Jackson. I think this applies to a lot of other animals, 
too. Great, non-patronising video. Thanks!! Axx﻿
comments.author: Alexandra Botham
